shortLinksItems.hed: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
shortLinksItems.dek: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous structure from afar.
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous monument from afar.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous monument from afar.

items.title: Arc de Triomphe
items.caption:
After climbing 284 steps to reach the top of the monument, you’ll be greeted by one of the most spectacular views of the Eiffel Tower—for a second or two, it looks like the tower is floating on top of the Parisian rooftops. From here, you can also see down the Champs-Élysées and all the way to La Défense, a major business district in Paris. The best time to visit is when the sun is starting to set over the city. If you’re really lucky, you'll see the Eiffel Tower sparkle for the first time that evening.

__Address__: Place Charles de Gaulle, 75008 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Charles de Gaulle Etoile (line: 1, 2 and 6)

items.title: Tour Montparnasse
items.caption:
Tour Montparnasse isn't the prettiest building in Paris, but the 689-foot skyscraper does offer some impressive views of the city (and it’s one of the few places with elevator access to the top). Take in a 360-degree view from the 56th floor; and if you dare, continue up to the terrace, which is the highest viewing platform in Paris. 

__Address__: 33 Avenue du Maine, 75015 Paris   
__Métro stop__: Montparnasse–Bienvenüe (line: 4, 6, 12 and 13)

items.title: [Hôtel Raphael](http://www.raphael-hotel.com)
items.caption:
Paris has its share of luxury hotels with magnificent views, but there’s something special about the experience from the rooftop terrace at Hôtel Raphael. Take a seat beneath rose-covered trellises and enjoy a drink or two with the Eiffel Tower looming on the horizon. This terrace is best during warm spring days and the summer (naturally), and it’s always a good idea to make a reservation for the terrace.

__Address__: 17 Avenue Kléber, 75116 Paris (16th arrondissement)  
__Métro stop__: Kléber (line: 6)

items.title: Printemps
items.caption:
From the terrace at shopping center Printemps (located on the roof, not far from the beauty products and home décor), you’ll be able to see both the Eiffel Tower and Sacré-Cœur, among other sites. Take a pause in between shops and rest your feet at the department store’s café, also located on the terrace.

__Address__: 64 Boulevard Haussmann, 75009 Paris   
__Métro stop__: Havre–Caumartin (line: 3 and 9)

items.title: Pont de Bir-Hakeim
items.caption:
Pont de Bir-Hakeim, which connects the 15th and 16th arrondissements, offers one of the best views of the Eiffel Tower. This now quite famous bridge (thanks to [movies like *Inception*](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-31/11-filming-locations-paris-you-can-visit/5)) has a symmetrical design—plus, you know, stunning views of the tower and the Seine—that makes it a popular spot for photographers. 

__Address__: Quai de Grenelle, 75015 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Bir-Hakeim (line: 6)

items.title: Cathédrale Notre Dame de Paris
items.caption:
Notre Dame is breathtaking on its own, but it also affords one of the best views in the city. Come prepared: You’ll have to climb about 387 steps to get to the top of the tower, but from there, you can see all along the Seine, to the Eiffel Tower, and over to Sacré-Cœur in Montmartre. Treat yourself to a few cream puffs at Odette or a warm cappuccino from Coutume Café (at the Finnish Institute) after your workout. 

__Address__: Parvis Notre-Dame - Place Jean-Paul II, 75004 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Saint-Michel/Cité (line: 4)

items.title: Rue Saint-Dominique
items.caption:
There’s nothing too spectacular about the view down Rue Saint-Dominique (in the 7th arrondissement), but it’s still one of the loveliest spots to admire the tower from afar. Some of the best gems in the city are right here, including Hôtel Thoumieux and its excellent brasserie and the sweet shop Aux Merveilleux de Fred.

__Address__: 79 Rue Saint-Dominique, 75007 Paris  
__Métro stop__: La Tour-Maubourg (line: 8)

items.title: Trocadero
items.caption:
All roads seem to lead to the Trocadero for a view of the Eiffel Tower's light show. As soon as the first twinkle starts, you’ll hear the crowd gasp and cheer while pulling out their phones and cameras to capture the magical moment. It’s free, always open, and accessible to everyone. To warm up frozen fingers and toes afterward, head to Carette for hot chocolate and macarons. 

__Address__: Place du Trocadéro et du 11 Novembre, 75116 Paris  
__Métro stop__: La Tour-Maubourg (line: 6 and 9)

items.title: Champ de Mars
items.caption:
The most classic view of the Eiffel Tower might be the one you’ll get from walking along the Champ de Mars. Some might call it boring, but we call it timeless. A picnic on the lawns around the tower’s base is a must once the weather allows it. Bring a bottle of champagne, bread, cheese, and charcuterie and stay until the tower sparkles for the first time that evening. It never gets old.

__Address__: Place Jacques Rueff, 75007 Paris  
__Métro stop__: École Militaire (line: 8)

fields.name: Carin Olsson
fields.shortBio: Through [Paris in Four Months](http://parisinfourmonths.com/), Carin shares her life in Paris through her photography.
fields.bio: In January 2012 Carin Olssen moved to Paris for a few months to learn the language, eat the amazing food, discover the city and to explore life in another country. After moving back to Stockholm, she immediately started to miss her months in Paris and decided to move back in January 2013. Through [Paris in Four Months](http://parisinfourmonths.com/) she shares parts of her life through photos, stories, and inspiration.

shortLinksItems.hed: Top 10 U.S. Hotels for Business Travelers: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
shortLinksItems.dek: Today’s business travelers are armed with smartphones, laptops, and tablets, making once de rigueur features of top business hotels—such as fax machines in rooms—less important. It also expands the arena for smaller upscale properties to capture a portion of this coveted market while retaining a stylish, sophisticated atmosphere. These 10 hotels in the United States as voted by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers well represents this new mix.

items.title: [10. Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco, CA](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 88.170*

*336 rooms (including 30 suites)*

Union Square, Chinatown, and Nob Hill are all walkable from this century-old white neoclassical Nob Hill landmark with Ionic columns, once the headquarters of a life insurance company. Traditional rooms marry walnut, mahogany, and local artwork. Dishes at the Lobby Lounge include a salmon BLT, fennel-pollen salmon, and Brandt Farms New York strip. The Club Level—where guests have their own business lounge and get snacks, hors d’oeuvres, and drinks throughout the day—kicks it up a notch.

items.title: [Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco, CA (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Between Union Square and Nob Hill

__Distance from airport:__ 15 miles north of San Francisco International Airport (SFO)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site, try the sophisticated Lounge (or the hotel's main restaurant, Parallel 37 for breakfast or dinner). Off-site, you're spoiled for choice in this city, but we like hopping a seven-minute cable car up California Street to Perbacco.

__Business center benefits:__ Full business center with administrative services, 23,000 square feet of meeting space with state-of-the-art audio/visual equipment.

__Loyalty program:__ Ritz-Carlton Rewards

items.title: [9. Waldorf Astoria Chicago, IL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/waldorf-astoria--chicago)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 89.556*

*188 guest rooms (138 are suites)*

Plush, spacious suites with fireplaces, Carrara marble baths, Salvatore Ferragamo toiletries, executive desks, terraces—it’s easy to see why readers ranked this Chicago hotel, designed to emulate 1920s Paris, No. 1 for accommodations. Amenities include complimentary Wi-Fi, 24-hour room service, and use of the hotel’s health club and spa, one of the best in the city. Pilates and Gyrotonic classes offered; courtesy car for destinations within a two-mile radius; steps to Michigan Avenue’s Magnificent Mile.

items.title: [Waldorf Astoria Chicago, IL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/waldorf-astoria--chicago)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Gold Coast

__Distance from airports:__ 18 miles to O’Hare International Airport (ORD); 20 miles to Midway Airport (MDW)

__Place for a power lunch:__ Balsan (on-site); Blackbird Restaurant or Gibson’s Bar & Steakhouse if you want something nearby.

__Business center benefits:__ PC and Mac computers, B&W printer, 24-hour access. A/V capabilities. Color printer and fax machine available at the front desk. Elegant meeting and event spaces, plus a boardroom.

__Loyalty program:__ Hilton HHonors

items.title: [8. Waldorf Astoria Orlando, FL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/waldorf-astoria-orlando)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 89.935*

*498 guest rooms (171 are suites)*

The Waldorf Astoria brand located within Walt Disney World translates to flawless service amid pristine surroundings. It’s also a good option for casual business gatherings on the greens—namely the resort’s 18-hole, 72-par Rees Jones-designed golf course and clubhouse. Post-business, relax poolside in a private cabana or indulge at the spa. Why not combine business with pleasure and invite the family for an extended stay? There's complimentary transit to the Disney theme parks.

items.title: [Waldorf Astoria, Orlando, FL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/waldorf-astoria-orlando)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Walt Disney World

__Distance from airport:__ 18 miles to Orlando International Airport (MCO)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Clubhouse Grill (part of the resort’s golf course; the Bull & Bear steakhouse, which would have been a more typical choice, isn’t open for lunch). Off-site: Citrus Restaurant in downtown Orlando

__Business center benefits:__ On-site FedEx Print and Ship Center that can also produce meeting and event needs such as banners, signs, graphics, etc. Dedicated conference staff for meetings and events.

__Loyalty program:__ Hilton HHonors

items.title: [7. The Kimberly Hotel, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/the-kimberly--new-york)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 90.604*

*192 guest rooms (134 are suites and executive rooms)*

Seal your deal while gazing at the Chrysler Building from the 30th-floor penthouse bar and lounge, Upstairs at the Kimberley. Guest rooms include Frette linens, two bottles of water per day, a kitchen or kitchenette, and a laptop-sized safe. There’s a charge for in-room Internet access, but weekday and Saturday copies of The New York Times are complimentary. Free passes to the nearby New York Health & Racquet Club. Catch a sunset cruise aboard the hotel’s 75-foot Kimberly Yacht, May through September.

items.title: [The Kimberly Hotel, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/the-kimberly--new-york)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Midtown

__Distance from airports:__ 7 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 17 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 18 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site Bistango (Italian restaurant even offers gluten-free options). Off-site Michael’s is a few blocks northwest on West 55th Street.

__Business center benefits:__ Computers and printer, 24-hour access. Free Wi-Fi. Conference room, full catering, and A/V equipment available. If the lobby’s business center is full, the concierge can print documents and boarding passes.

items.title: [6. Langham Place Fifth Avenue, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/langham-place-new-york--formerly-the-setai-fifth-avenue-)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 90.933*

*214 guest rooms (57 are suites)*

Oversized rooms with Duxiana beds and Pratesi linens and marble baths coupled with complimentary amenities—Wi-Fi, shoe shine, garment pressing, coffee and snacks in the lobby—and excellent service keep business travelers happy at this luxury hotel. Spa, 24-hour fitness center with personal trainers, and Julian Farel Salon are on-site. There’s even a chauffeured Quattroporte Maserati available to take guests to any location in Manhattan.

items.title: [Langham Place Fifth Avenue, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/langham-place-new-york--formerly-the-setai-fifth-avenue-)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Midtown

__Distance from airports:__ 9 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 16 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 17 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Ai Fiori (Michelin-starred; $45 prix fixe lunch). Off-site: Eleven Madison Park, a short stroll south down Fifth Avenue.

__Business center benefits:__ 24-hour access, computers and printers, video conferencing and other A/V capabilities. Dedicated meetings and events team.

__Loyalty program:__ Ouida Rewards

items.title: [5. The Jefferson, Washington, D.C.](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/washington/the-jefferson--washington-d-c-)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.020*

*95 rooms (20 are suites)*

It’s hard to imagine this historic hotel in a posh Beaux Arts building inspired by its namesake’s Monticello home being any more accommodating, with complimentary amenities like 24-hour butler service, Wi-Fi, garment pressing, shoe shine, calls (domestic and international), and access to the private University Club. Black belts and custom Jefferson bow ties are at hand should you land a last-minute black-tie invitation. Arrive in style via the house Mercedes.

items.title: [The Jefferson, Washington, D.C. (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/washington/the-jefferson--washington-d-c-)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Downtown

__Distance from airports:__ 27 miles to Dulles International Airport (IAD); 5.5 miles to Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: The Greenhouse (unfortunately Plume is open only for dinner). Off-site: Carmine’s or RIS

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, 24-hour access. Intimate event spaces available for private functions.

__Loyalty program:__ iPrefer

items.title: [4. Hotel Icon, Houston, TX](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/houston/hotel-icon)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.234*

*Ranked #1 for Rooms, Design, and Value.*

*135 guest rooms (18 are suites)*

Readers voted this hotel in a landmarked, neoclassical building best for both design and value. Retained architectural details from its Union National Bank origins include two-story marble columns, vintage elevators, and the vault behind the front desk. The large, recently renovated rooms have Jacuzzi tubs, Keurig coffee makers, a work desk with task lighting, oversized safes for laptops, and free Wi-Fi. Walking distance to the convention center and many businesses, bars and restaurants. It’s the only business district hotel on Houston’s light rail line.

items.title: [Hotel Icon, Houston, TX (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/houston/hotel-icon)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Downtown Business District

__Distance from airports:__ 20 miles to Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH); 13 miles to Hobby Airport (HOU)

__Place for power lunch:__ On-site: The Line & Lariat. Off-site: Tony’s

__Business center benefits:__ 24-hour access. Just two blocks from the city's courthouse, the hotel offers "Legal War Rooms"–transforming suites, or entire floors, into satellite offices.

__Loyalty program:__ Marriott Rewards

items.title: [3. Trump International Hotel & Tower, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/trump-international-hotel---tower--new-york)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.634*

*176 rooms (120 are suites)*

Earning nods from readers in 2014 for best hotel in New York City, it’s no surprise this property with floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking Central Park is also New York’s top ranked business hotel. Bespoke services include personalized stationery and business cards (upon request), custom stocked kitchens, and access to Trump Attaché’s VIP program, offering in-room exercise machines, use of house cars, personal shopping, and more. Fitness club and Trump Spa access, free Wi-Fi, and—best of all—24-hour in-room dining from Jean-Georges are available.

items.title: [Trump International Hotel & Tower, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/trump-international-hotel---tower--new-york)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Columbus Circle, Upper West Side

__Distance from airports:__ 11 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 17 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 17.4 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: lauded Jean-Georges and Nougatine. Off-site: A Voce Columbus

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, 24-hour access. Can send documents to print and have staff deliver them to your room. In-room printers and laptops available upon request. Executive boardroom.

__Loyalty program:__ Trump Card

items.title: [2. The Langham, Chicago, IL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/the-langham-chicago)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.991*

*316 rooms (48 are suites)*

Sleek, contemporary furnishings fit well in this landmarked minimalist Mies van der Rohe skyscraper that IBM once called home. Executive room guests have access to the Club Lounge, with private registration, butler services, and special amenities. Rooms feature a stocked ‘cellarette’ portable wine bar and touch-button opaque privacy glass in the bathroom. Don’t miss the hotel’s traditional afternoon tea, complete with Wedgwood china. For fitness there’s a pool and gym, and the indulgent Chuan Spa for relaxation. Female road warriors take note: The gift shop sells nail polish in Langham’s signature pink.

items.title: [The Langham, Chicago, IL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/the-langham-chicago)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ River North

__Distance from airports:__ 18 miles to O’Hare International Airport (ORD), 20 miles to Midway Airport (MDW)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Travelle. Off-site: The Gage

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, A/V services, 24-hour access. Eight function rooms, four boardrooms, and a private Cinema Suite screening room.

__Loyalty program:__ Ouida Rewards

items.title: [1. The Peninsula, Beverly Hills, Los Angeles, CA](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/beverly-hills/the-peninsula--beverly-hills)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 93.214*

*Ranked #1 for Service, Dining, and Location.*

*193 guest rooms (with 36 suites and 17 garden villas)*

Inject your business trip with a dose of glamour at this discreet hideaway with a lush rooftop pool, private cabanas, and gardens—all within walking distance of Rodeo Drive. It received top marks from readers for service, food, and neighborhood categories. Perks include 24-hour check in and check out, long-term luggage storage, and a fleet of luxury house cars available for pick-up or drop-off within a 12-mile radius. Frequent guests are treated to monogrammed pillows. Even pets are pampered with personalized towels, beds, and treats. For those on the go, order a Pen Air gourmet meal to take on your departing flight.

items.title: [The Peninsula, Beverly Hills, Los Angeles, CA (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/beverly-hills/the-peninsula--beverly-hills)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Beverly Hills

__Distance from airports:__ 11 miles to Los Angeles International Airport (LAX), 5 miles to Santa Monica Municipal Airport (SMO), 13 miles to Burbank Bob Hope Airport (BUR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: The Belvedere or The Polo Lounge. Off-site: Soho House

__Business center benefits:__ Computers and printers; staffed from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., after which the concierge and communications staff can assist with requests. On-site notary services; private event coordinators. Complimentary Wi-Fi throughout the hotel.

__Loyalty program:__ PenClub (invitation only)

fields.name: Donna M. Airoldi
fields.shortBio: Donna M. Airoldi is a Brooklyn-based freelance writer and editor.
fields.bio: Donna M. Airoldi, a New York City-based freelance writer and editor, has covered travel and other topics for more than 10 years. She's a contract analyst and editor for the travel research company Phocuswright, a columnist for DNAinfo, and her work has appeared in *Time Out New York*, [TravelChannel.com](http://www.travelchannel.com),  *The Real Deal South Florida*, and other publications—including a chapter in the upcoming *Fodor's* Brooklyn guidebook.

shortLinksItems.dek: Part of the fun of a long road trip is spotting cool roadside attractions—and few will give you as much insight to a state as its welcome signs. Here, we've gathered 50 signs from all 50 states—which ones do you recognize?
shortLinksItems.hed: 50 Welcome Signs for the 50 United States of America

items.title: ALABAMA
items.caption: When Alabama decided to replace its old welcome signs (which read "Welcome to Alabama the Beautiful"), naturally they turned to the best-known song about the state: Lynyrd Skynyrd's 1974 Southern rock anthem.

items.title: ALASKA
items.caption: We applaud Alaska for not succumbing to the temptation to put up a green-and-white sign similar to other states'; its wooden welcome emblem is something you'd actually want to pose with in a photo.

items.title: ARIZONA
items.caption: Arizona's flag and its most recognizable tourist landmark—that would be the Grand Canyon—are the focal points of its interstate signs.

items.title: ARKANSAS
items.caption: Did you know that Arkansas's nickname is "The Natural State"? If you've crossed the state's borders, you should: The moniker—a reference to its plethora of mountains, lakes, hot springs, and more—is right there on the welcome signs.

items.title: CALIFORNIA
items.caption: Instead of using a more recognizable symbol on its state signs—like the coastline, or an orange, or something like that—California's DOT instead chose to add a poppy, the state flower, to its highway signs.

items.title: COLORADO
items.caption: Colorado's cheerful, rustic signs (there are 40 throughout the state) have become landmarks in and of themselves, with each one weighing about 150 pounds.

items.title: CONNECTICUT
items.caption: Connecticut may be full of surprises, but this welcome sign—a plain blue-and-white number—is not one of them.

items.title: DELAWARE
items.caption: Delaware's sign is nice and all, but in this case, we can only think of Wayne Campbell: "[Hi…I'm in Delaware.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DDGDgc1qNCA)"

items.title: FLORIDA
items.caption: Florida calls out some its most recognizable state symbols—the palm tree and the orange—on its welcome signs. (No Mickey Mouse, though. Huh.) The state DOT plans to replace these signs with bigger and more photogenic ones by 2015.

items.title: GEORGIA
items.caption: "Georgia On My Mind" is the official song of the Peach State, so it's only fitting that a snippet of the lyrics (along with a fuzzy peach) ended up on its welcome signs.

items.title: HAWAII
items.caption: Fun fact: Hawaii doesn't have specific state welcome signs on its highways; instead, they're located at Hawaiian airports, like the one in Honolulu.

items.title: IDAHO
items.caption: Not even a potato, Idaho? Fine.

items.title: ILLINOIS
items.caption: Of course Illinois would call out its most famous son: 16th President Abraham Lincoln, who lived in the state, became a congressman there, and was buried in Springfield after his 1865 assassination.

items.title: INDIANA
items.caption: Indiana's nickname, "The Crossroads of America," is a reference to the fact that several major interstate roads passed through the state. And thus, it ended up on its highway signs.

items.title: IOWA
items.caption: One of Iowa's biggest tourist attractions is the _Field of Dreams_ house, so of course that movie is referenced on the state's highway signs.

items.title: KANSAS
items.caption: Kansas's signs are a mishmash of its state seal (emblazoned with the Latin phrase "Ad Astra per Aspera," translating to "To the Stars Through Difficulties") and the state flag, which features a sunflower, the official state flower.

items.title: KENTUCKY
items.caption: Kentucky's state motto is "Unbridled Spirit"—like horses, because of the Kentucky Derby, see—and so it ended up on the state signs, which also feature a subtle horse illustration.

items.title: LOUISIANA
items.caption: A fleur-de-lis and the phrase "Bienvenue en Louisiane" are shoutouts to Louisiana's Cajun French culture, still a vital part of the state's identity.
items.credit: © David R. Frazier Photolibrary, Inc. / Alamy

items.title: MAINE
items.caption: We'll take Maine's word that things in Maine are, indeed, the way life should be.

items.title: MARYLAND
items.caption: Maryland's signs are positively cluttered with state iconography: The red, yellow, and black state flag is perched above black-eyed Susans, the state flower.

items.title: MASSACHUSETTS
items.caption: We can't say for sure whether you'll actually see a chickadee sitting on a Mayflower when you visit Massachusetts (both are emblems of the state), but you sure will on its highway signs.
items.credit: Massachussetts Office of Travel and Tourism

items.title: MICHIGAN
items.caption: The Great Lakes State adopted the "Pure Michigan" slogan in 2006 as part of an advertising campaign, and its since permeated much of the official tourism literature in the state—including the welcome signs.

items.title: MINNESOTA
items.caption: University of Minnesota students are responsible for the current welcome sign, created in 1996; the Department of Transportation wanted to hark back to the [old highway markers](http://www.dot.state.mn.us/restareas/entry-signs/es-history.html), but with a more modern design.

items.title: MISSISSIPPI
items.caption: Mississippi has had several state signs, including one that highlighted its place in rock 'n' roll history; this one is simple but effective, with the state flower—the magnolia—perched in a corner.

items.title: MISSOURI
items.caption: Missouri's slightly befuddling nickname, "The Show Me State," greets travelers as they cross state lines.

items.title: MONTANA
items.caption: Montana's welcome signs got a makeover in 2013, replacing decades-old iconography with images that highlight some of the unique elements of the state: cowboys, Bighorn Canyon, and the like.

items.title: NEBRASKA
items.caption: In case you didn't know, Nebraska is the home of Arbor Day. You learn something new every day.…

items.title: NEVADA
items.caption: The "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas" sign is more well known, but these welcome signs exist, too; they complement a similar license plate that was introduced in 1989.

items.title: NEW HAMPSHIRE
items.caption: Following a rebranding campaign, New Hampshire also updated its welcome signs in 2012—the French is a nod to its Canadian visitors, a major influence on the state's culture.
items.credit: Kethaneni/Courtesy New Hampshire Division of Travel and Tourism

items.title: NEW JERSEY
items.caption: New Jersey has several welcome signs, and this one is a darn sight nicer than the ones that welcome you to the Turnpike, that's for sure.

items.title: NEW MEXICO
items.caption: New Mexico's welcome signs reference its state flag, with red and yellow coloring, and its agriculture, with red or green chiles on various signs.

items.title: NEW YORK
items.caption: How long do you think it'll be before the lyrics from "Empire State of Mind" end up on New York's welcome signs? We give it another five years.

items.title: NORTH CAROLINA
items.caption: North Carolina keeps it simple and classy, with its state flag the only adornment on its highway signs.

items.title: NORTH DAKOTA
items.caption: Depending on where you enter North Dakota, you might see a different sign: This one, featuring the visage of President Theodore Roosevelt, is an entrance to the state's western region (conveniently, where Theodore Roosevelt National Park is located).

items.title: OHIO
items.caption: Another simple, clean design. We dig it, Ohio.

items.title: OKLAHOMA
items.caption: Less a sign and more a big monument to the state, this sign along an Oklahoma interstate is more imposing than your standard-issue welcome wagon.

items.title: OREGON
items.caption: Travelers heading into Oregon from California will see this massive sign along Interstate 5, where it was installed in 2010.

items.title: PENNSYLVANIA
items.caption: The slogan "State of Independence" was added to Pennsylvania's welcome signs in 2004, after a campaign to remind folks of its place in American history.

items.title: RHODE ISLAND
items.caption: These may be the newest welcome signs in the USA: Five of these markers were installed earlier this summer, with another two to follow in the coming months.
items.credit: Courtesy Rhode Island Department of Transportation

items.title: SOUTH CAROLINA
items.caption: Though South Carolina has these fairly staid markers along its interstates, we'd be remiss if we didn't mention [South of the Border](http://www.thesouthoftheborder.com/history/), the supremely tacky roadside stop that's just over the North Carolina-South Carolina border.

items.title: SOUTH DAKOTA
items.caption: What else do you put on a welcome sign for South Dakota than the state's—nay, one of the country's—biggest attractions?

items.title: TENNESSEE
items.caption: Why "the Volunteer State"? It's a [holdover from the War of 1812](http://www.tennessee.gov/tsla/exhibits/veterans/mexicanamerican.htm), when thousands of Tennessee men willingly went to fight against the British.

items.title: TEXAS
items.caption: We were expecting something bigger, bolder, and…well, more Texas than these signs. But the state flag and the DOT's "Drive Friendly" motto are nice too, we guess.

items.title: UTAH
items.caption: Utah created seven different welcome signs, which are placed at strategic points around the state. This one, for example, can be found around the Lake Powell region; another, featuring a ski bunny, is installed near Park City and other popular ski spots.

items.title: VERMONT
items.caption: Vermont keeps things simple: illustration of Green Mountains, state name, nickname that echoes the whole mountain theme. Boom. Done.
items.credit: Courtesy Vermont Department of Tourism & Marketing

items.title: VIRGINIA
items.caption: Similar to its fellow commonwealth, Massachusetts, Virginia festooned its welcome signs with the state bird (the cardinal) sitting atop the state flower (an American dogwood).

items.title: WASHINGTON
items.caption: Way to keep it simple, Washington.

items.title: WEST VIRGINIA
items.caption: "Wild and Wonderful," a popular slogan in West Virginia, was added to the welcome signs in 2007.

items.title: WISCONSIN
items.caption: Wisconsin's welcome signs are charmingly retro: 23 of these markers, made from redwood, were installed along major highways beginning in 1958—and remarkably, they're still standing.

items.title: WYOMING
items.caption:
Don't expect to see Wyoming's welcome signs for too long: According to the state's tourism office, they change out every so often, along with the state license plates.




What's your favorite state sign? [Vote now in our poll](http://poll.fm/4vxa0), and see which welcome sign fellow travelers like best.




**More ways to celebrate America:**




[Which State Has the Coolest License Plate in America?](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/best-license-plate-vote)




[10 American Monuments to See In Your Lifetime](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/patriotic-4th-of-july-monuments-and-destinations)




[The 10 Biggest 4th of July Fireworks Displays in the U.S.](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/the-10-biggest-fireworks-displays-in-the-us)

shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Part of the fun of a long road trip is spotting cool roadside attractions—and few will give you as much insight to a state as its welcome signs. Here, we've gathered 50 signs from all 50 states—which ones do you recognize?
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: 50 Welcome Signs for the 50 United States of America
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Part of the fun of a long road trip is spotting cool roadside attractions—and few will give you as much insight to a state as its welcome signs. Here, we've gathered 50 signs from all 50 states—which ones do you recognize?
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: 50 Welcome Signs for the 50 United States of America

fields.title: COLORADO
fields.caption: Colorado's cheerful, rustic signs (there are 40 throughout the state) have become landmarks in and of themselves, with each one weighing about 150 pounds.

fields.name: Amy Plitt
fields.shortBio: Amy Plitt is the digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Amy Plitt is a Brooklyn-based writer and digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.* She has written for such publications as *Rolling Stone,* the A.V. Club, *Foam*, Made Man, *Mental Floss*, and *Time Out New York*, where she was a staff editor. She's also the author of *[Subway Adventure Guide: New York City](http://www.triumphbooks.com/subway-adventure-guide--new-york-city-products-9781629370774.php?page_id=21)* (Triumph Books), a guidebook about the ends of New York City's subway lines. When she travels, she's on the lookout for excellent local beers, weird museums, and nerdy historical sites.

featureContentItems.hed: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
featureContentItems.dek: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous structure from afar.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous monument from afar.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: Where to Get the Best Views of the Eiffel Tower
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Seeing the Eiffel Tower against the skyline is worth a trip to Paris—here are the best spots in the city to see the famous monument from afar.

items.title: Arc de Triomphe
items.caption:
After climbing 284 steps to reach the top of the monument, you’ll be greeted by one of the most spectacular views of the Eiffel Tower—for a second or two, it looks like the tower is floating on top of the Parisian rooftops. From here, you can also see down the Champs-Élysées and all the way to La Défense, a major business district in Paris. The best time to visit is when the sun is starting to set over the city. If you’re really lucky, you'll see the Eiffel Tower sparkle for the first time that evening.

__Address__: Place Charles de Gaulle, 75008 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Charles de Gaulle Etoile (line: 1, 2 and 6)

items.title: Tour Montparnasse
items.caption:
Tour Montparnasse isn't the prettiest building in Paris, but the 689-foot skyscraper does offer some impressive views of the city (and it’s one of the few places with elevator access to the top). Take in a 360-degree view from the 56th floor; and if you dare, continue up to the terrace, which is the highest viewing platform in Paris. 

__Address__: 33 Avenue du Maine, 75015 Paris   
__Métro stop__: Montparnasse–Bienvenüe (line: 4, 6, 12 and 13)

items.title: [Hôtel Raphael](http://www.raphael-hotel.com)
items.caption:
Paris has its share of luxury hotels with magnificent views, but there’s something special about the experience from the rooftop terrace at Hôtel Raphael. Take a seat beneath rose-covered trellises and enjoy a drink or two with the Eiffel Tower looming on the horizon. This terrace is best during warm spring days and the summer (naturally), and it’s always a good idea to make a reservation for the terrace.

__Address__: 17 Avenue Kléber, 75116 Paris (16th arrondissement)  
__Métro stop__: Kléber (line: 6)

items.title: Printemps
items.caption:
From the terrace at shopping center Printemps (located on the roof, not far from the beauty products and home décor), you’ll be able to see both the Eiffel Tower and Sacré-Cœur, among other sites. Take a pause in between shops and rest your feet at the department store’s café, also located on the terrace.

__Address__: 64 Boulevard Haussmann, 75009 Paris   
__Métro stop__: Havre–Caumartin (line: 3 and 9)

items.title: Pont de Bir-Hakeim
items.caption:
Pont de Bir-Hakeim, which connects the 15th and 16th arrondissements, offers one of the best views of the Eiffel Tower. This now quite famous bridge (thanks to [movies like *Inception*](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-10-31/11-filming-locations-paris-you-can-visit/5)) has a symmetrical design—plus, you know, stunning views of the tower and the Seine—that makes it a popular spot for photographers. 

__Address__: Quai de Grenelle, 75015 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Bir-Hakeim (line: 6)

items.title: Cathédrale Notre Dame de Paris
items.caption:
Notre Dame is breathtaking on its own, but it also affords one of the best views in the city. Come prepared: You’ll have to climb about 387 steps to get to the top of the tower, but from there, you can see all along the Seine, to the Eiffel Tower, and over to Sacré-Cœur in Montmartre. Treat yourself to a few cream puffs at Odette or a warm cappuccino from Coutume Café (at the Finnish Institute) after your workout. 

__Address__: Parvis Notre-Dame - Place Jean-Paul II, 75004 Paris  
__Métro stop__: Saint-Michel/Cité (line: 4)

items.title: Rue Saint-Dominique
items.caption:
There’s nothing too spectacular about the view down Rue Saint-Dominique (in the 7th arrondissement), but it’s still one of the loveliest spots to admire the tower from afar. Some of the best gems in the city are right here, including Hôtel Thoumieux and its excellent brasserie and the sweet shop Aux Merveilleux de Fred.

__Address__: 79 Rue Saint-Dominique, 75007 Paris  
__Métro stop__: La Tour-Maubourg (line: 8)

items.title: Trocadero
items.caption:
All roads seem to lead to the Trocadero for a view of the Eiffel Tower's light show. As soon as the first twinkle starts, you’ll hear the crowd gasp and cheer while pulling out their phones and cameras to capture the magical moment. It’s free, always open, and accessible to everyone. To warm up frozen fingers and toes afterward, head to Carette for hot chocolate and macarons. 

__Address__: Place du Trocadéro et du 11 Novembre, 75116 Paris  
__Métro stop__: La Tour-Maubourg (line: 6 and 9)

items.title: Champ de Mars
items.caption:
The most classic view of the Eiffel Tower might be the one you’ll get from walking along the Champ de Mars. Some might call it boring, but we call it timeless. A picnic on the lawns around the tower’s base is a must once the weather allows it. Bring a bottle of champagne, bread, cheese, and charcuterie and stay until the tower sparkles for the first time that evening. It never gets old.

__Address__: Place Jacques Rueff, 75007 Paris  
__Métro stop__: École Militaire (line: 8)

fields.name: Carin Olsson
fields.shortBio: Through [Paris in Four Months](http://parisinfourmonths.com/), Carin shares her life in Paris through her photography.
fields.bio: In January 2012 Carin Olssen moved to Paris for a few months to learn the language, eat the amazing food, discover the city and to explore life in another country. After moving back to Stockholm, she immediately started to miss her months in Paris and decided to move back in January 2013. Through [Paris in Four Months](http://parisinfourmonths.com/) she shares parts of her life through photos, stories, and inspiration.

featureContentItems.hed: Top 10 U.S. Hotels for Business Travelers: Readers' Choice Awards 2014
featureContentItems.dek: Today’s business travelers are armed with smartphones, laptops, and tablets, making once de rigueur features of top business hotels—such as fax machines in rooms—less important. It also expands the arena for smaller upscale properties to capture a portion of this coveted market while retaining a stylish, sophisticated atmosphere. These 10 hotels in the United States as voted by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers well represents this new mix.

items.title: [10. Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco, CA](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 88.170*

*336 rooms (including 30 suites)*

Union Square, Chinatown, and Nob Hill are all walkable from this century-old white neoclassical Nob Hill landmark with Ionic columns, once the headquarters of a life insurance company. Traditional rooms marry walnut, mahogany, and local artwork. Dishes at the Lobby Lounge include a salmon BLT, fennel-pollen salmon, and Brandt Farms New York strip. The Club Level—where guests have their own business lounge and get snacks, hors d’oeuvres, and drinks throughout the day—kicks it up a notch.

items.title: [Ritz-Carlton, San Francisco, CA (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/san-francisco/ritz-carlton--san-francisco)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Between Union Square and Nob Hill

__Distance from airport:__ 15 miles north of San Francisco International Airport (SFO)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site, try the sophisticated Lounge (or the hotel's main restaurant, Parallel 37 for breakfast or dinner). Off-site, you're spoiled for choice in this city, but we like hopping a seven-minute cable car up California Street to Perbacco.

__Business center benefits:__ Full business center with administrative services, 23,000 square feet of meeting space with state-of-the-art audio/visual equipment.

__Loyalty program:__ Ritz-Carlton Rewards

items.title: [9. Waldorf Astoria Chicago, IL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/waldorf-astoria--chicago)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 89.556*

*188 guest rooms (138 are suites)*

Plush, spacious suites with fireplaces, Carrara marble baths, Salvatore Ferragamo toiletries, executive desks, terraces—it’s easy to see why readers ranked this Chicago hotel, designed to emulate 1920s Paris, No. 1 for accommodations. Amenities include complimentary Wi-Fi, 24-hour room service, and use of the hotel’s health club and spa, one of the best in the city. Pilates and Gyrotonic classes offered; courtesy car for destinations within a two-mile radius; steps to Michigan Avenue’s Magnificent Mile.

items.title: [Waldorf Astoria Chicago, IL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/waldorf-astoria--chicago)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Gold Coast

__Distance from airports:__ 18 miles to O’Hare International Airport (ORD); 20 miles to Midway Airport (MDW)

__Place for a power lunch:__ Balsan (on-site); Blackbird Restaurant or Gibson’s Bar & Steakhouse if you want something nearby.

__Business center benefits:__ PC and Mac computers, B&W printer, 24-hour access. A/V capabilities. Color printer and fax machine available at the front desk. Elegant meeting and event spaces, plus a boardroom.

__Loyalty program:__ Hilton HHonors

items.title: [8. Waldorf Astoria Orlando, FL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/waldorf-astoria-orlando)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 89.935*

*498 guest rooms (171 are suites)*

The Waldorf Astoria brand located within Walt Disney World translates to flawless service amid pristine surroundings. It’s also a good option for casual business gatherings on the greens—namely the resort’s 18-hole, 72-par Rees Jones-designed golf course and clubhouse. Post-business, relax poolside in a private cabana or indulge at the spa. Why not combine business with pleasure and invite the family for an extended stay? There's complimentary transit to the Disney theme parks.

items.title: [Waldorf Astoria, Orlando, FL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/orlando/waldorf-astoria-orlando)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Walt Disney World

__Distance from airport:__ 18 miles to Orlando International Airport (MCO)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Clubhouse Grill (part of the resort’s golf course; the Bull & Bear steakhouse, which would have been a more typical choice, isn’t open for lunch). Off-site: Citrus Restaurant in downtown Orlando

__Business center benefits:__ On-site FedEx Print and Ship Center that can also produce meeting and event needs such as banners, signs, graphics, etc. Dedicated conference staff for meetings and events.

__Loyalty program:__ Hilton HHonors

items.title: [7. The Kimberly Hotel, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/the-kimberly--new-york)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 90.604*

*192 guest rooms (134 are suites and executive rooms)*

Seal your deal while gazing at the Chrysler Building from the 30th-floor penthouse bar and lounge, Upstairs at the Kimberley. Guest rooms include Frette linens, two bottles of water per day, a kitchen or kitchenette, and a laptop-sized safe. There’s a charge for in-room Internet access, but weekday and Saturday copies of The New York Times are complimentary. Free passes to the nearby New York Health & Racquet Club. Catch a sunset cruise aboard the hotel’s 75-foot Kimberly Yacht, May through September.

items.title: [The Kimberly Hotel, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/the-kimberly--new-york)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Midtown

__Distance from airports:__ 7 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 17 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 18 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site Bistango (Italian restaurant even offers gluten-free options). Off-site Michael’s is a few blocks northwest on West 55th Street.

__Business center benefits:__ Computers and printer, 24-hour access. Free Wi-Fi. Conference room, full catering, and A/V equipment available. If the lobby’s business center is full, the concierge can print documents and boarding passes.

items.title: [6. Langham Place Fifth Avenue, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/langham-place-new-york--formerly-the-setai-fifth-avenue-)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 90.933*

*214 guest rooms (57 are suites)*

Oversized rooms with Duxiana beds and Pratesi linens and marble baths coupled with complimentary amenities—Wi-Fi, shoe shine, garment pressing, coffee and snacks in the lobby—and excellent service keep business travelers happy at this luxury hotel. Spa, 24-hour fitness center with personal trainers, and Julian Farel Salon are on-site. There’s even a chauffeured Quattroporte Maserati available to take guests to any location in Manhattan.

items.title: [Langham Place Fifth Avenue, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/langham-place-new-york--formerly-the-setai-fifth-avenue-)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Midtown

__Distance from airports:__ 9 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 16 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 17 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Ai Fiori (Michelin-starred; $45 prix fixe lunch). Off-site: Eleven Madison Park, a short stroll south down Fifth Avenue.

__Business center benefits:__ 24-hour access, computers and printers, video conferencing and other A/V capabilities. Dedicated meetings and events team.

__Loyalty program:__ Ouida Rewards

items.title: [5. The Jefferson, Washington, D.C.](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/washington/the-jefferson--washington-d-c-)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.020*

*95 rooms (20 are suites)*

It’s hard to imagine this historic hotel in a posh Beaux Arts building inspired by its namesake’s Monticello home being any more accommodating, with complimentary amenities like 24-hour butler service, Wi-Fi, garment pressing, shoe shine, calls (domestic and international), and access to the private University Club. Black belts and custom Jefferson bow ties are at hand should you land a last-minute black-tie invitation. Arrive in style via the house Mercedes.

items.title: [The Jefferson, Washington, D.C. (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/washington/the-jefferson--washington-d-c-)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Downtown

__Distance from airports:__ 27 miles to Dulles International Airport (IAD); 5.5 miles to Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: The Greenhouse (unfortunately Plume is open only for dinner). Off-site: Carmine’s or RIS

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, 24-hour access. Intimate event spaces available for private functions.

__Loyalty program:__ iPrefer

items.title: [4. Hotel Icon, Houston, TX](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/houston/hotel-icon)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.234*

*Ranked #1 for Rooms, Design, and Value.*

*135 guest rooms (18 are suites)*

Readers voted this hotel in a landmarked, neoclassical building best for both design and value. Retained architectural details from its Union National Bank origins include two-story marble columns, vintage elevators, and the vault behind the front desk. The large, recently renovated rooms have Jacuzzi tubs, Keurig coffee makers, a work desk with task lighting, oversized safes for laptops, and free Wi-Fi. Walking distance to the convention center and many businesses, bars and restaurants. It’s the only business district hotel on Houston’s light rail line.

items.title: [Hotel Icon, Houston, TX (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/houston/hotel-icon)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Downtown Business District

__Distance from airports:__ 20 miles to Bush Intercontinental Airport (IAH); 13 miles to Hobby Airport (HOU)

__Place for power lunch:__ On-site: The Line & Lariat. Off-site: Tony’s

__Business center benefits:__ 24-hour access. Just two blocks from the city's courthouse, the hotel offers "Legal War Rooms"–transforming suites, or entire floors, into satellite offices.

__Loyalty program:__ Marriott Rewards

items.title: [3. Trump International Hotel & Tower, New York, NY](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/trump-international-hotel---tower--new-york)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.634*

*176 rooms (120 are suites)*

Earning nods from readers in 2014 for best hotel in New York City, it’s no surprise this property with floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking Central Park is also New York’s top ranked business hotel. Bespoke services include personalized stationery and business cards (upon request), custom stocked kitchens, and access to Trump Attaché’s VIP program, offering in-room exercise machines, use of house cars, personal shopping, and more. Fitness club and Trump Spa access, free Wi-Fi, and—best of all—24-hour in-room dining from Jean-Georges are available.

items.title: [Trump International Hotel & Tower, New York, NY (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/new-york/trump-international-hotel---tower--new-york)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Columbus Circle, Upper West Side

__Distance from airports:__ 11 miles to LaGuardia Airport (LGA), 17 miles to John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK), 17.4 miles to Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: lauded Jean-Georges and Nougatine. Off-site: A Voce Columbus

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, 24-hour access. Can send documents to print and have staff deliver them to your room. In-room printers and laptops available upon request. Executive boardroom.

__Loyalty program:__ Trump Card

items.title: [2. The Langham, Chicago, IL](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/the-langham-chicago)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 91.991*

*316 rooms (48 are suites)*

Sleek, contemporary furnishings fit well in this landmarked minimalist Mies van der Rohe skyscraper that IBM once called home. Executive room guests have access to the Club Lounge, with private registration, butler services, and special amenities. Rooms feature a stocked ‘cellarette’ portable wine bar and touch-button opaque privacy glass in the bathroom. Don’t miss the hotel’s traditional afternoon tea, complete with Wedgwood china. For fitness there’s a pool and gym, and the indulgent Chuan Spa for relaxation. Female road warriors take note: The gift shop sells nail polish in Langham’s signature pink.

items.title: [The Langham, Chicago, IL (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/the-langham-chicago)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ River North

__Distance from airports:__ 18 miles to O’Hare International Airport (ORD), 20 miles to Midway Airport (MDW)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: Travelle. Off-site: The Gage

__Business center benefits:__ Computer and printer, A/V services, 24-hour access. Eight function rooms, four boardrooms, and a private Cinema Suite screening room.

__Loyalty program:__ Ouida Rewards

items.title: [1. The Peninsula, Beverly Hills, Los Angeles, CA](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/beverly-hills/the-peninsula--beverly-hills)
items.caption:
*Readers' Business Rating: 93.214*

*Ranked #1 for Service, Dining, and Location.*

*193 guest rooms (with 36 suites and 17 garden villas)*

Inject your business trip with a dose of glamour at this discreet hideaway with a lush rooftop pool, private cabanas, and gardens—all within walking distance of Rodeo Drive. It received top marks from readers for service, food, and neighborhood categories. Perks include 24-hour check in and check out, long-term luggage storage, and a fleet of luxury house cars available for pick-up or drop-off within a 12-mile radius. Frequent guests are treated to monogrammed pillows. Even pets are pampered with personalized towels, beds, and treats. For those on the go, order a Pen Air gourmet meal to take on your departing flight.

items.title: [The Peninsula, Beverly Hills, Los Angeles, CA (cont.)](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/beverly-hills/the-peninsula--beverly-hills)
items.caption:
__Neighborhood:__ Beverly Hills

__Distance from airports:__ 11 miles to Los Angeles International Airport (LAX), 5 miles to Santa Monica Municipal Airport (SMO), 13 miles to Burbank Bob Hope Airport (BUR)

__Place for a power lunch:__ On-site: The Belvedere or The Polo Lounge. Off-site: Soho House

__Business center benefits:__ Computers and printers; staffed from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., after which the concierge and communications staff can assist with requests. On-site notary services; private event coordinators. Complimentary Wi-Fi throughout the hotel.

__Loyalty program:__ PenClub (invitation only)


----------

featureContentItems.seoDescription: Today’s business travelers are armed with smartphones, laptops, and tablets, making once de rigueur features of top business hotels—such as fax machines in rooms—less important. It also expands the arena for smaller upscale properties to capture a portion of this coveted market while retaining a stylish, sophisticated atmosphere. These top business hotels in the United States as voted by *Condé Nast Traveler* readers well represents this new mix.

fields.shortBio: Donna M. Airoldi is a Brooklyn-based freelance writer and editor.
fields.bio: Donna M. Airoldi, a New York City-based freelance writer and editor, has covered travel and other topics for more than 10 years. She's a contract analyst and editor for the travel research company Phocuswright, a columnist for DNAinfo, and her work has appeared in *Time Out New York*, [TravelChannel.com](http://www.travelchannel.com),  *The Real Deal South Florida*, and other publications—including a chapter in the upcoming *Fodor's* Brooklyn guidebook.

featureContentItems.dek: Part of the fun of a long road trip is spotting cool roadside attractions—and few will give you as much insight to a state as its welcome signs. Here, we've gathered 50 signs from all 50 states—which ones do you recognize?
featureContentItems.hed: 50 Welcome Signs for the 50 United States of America

items.title: ALABAMA
items.caption: When Alabama decided to replace its old welcome signs (which read "Welcome to Alabama the Beautiful"), naturally they turned to the best-known song about the state: Lynyrd Skynyrd's 1974 Southern rock anthem.

items.title: ALASKA
items.caption: We applaud Alaska for not succumbing to the temptation to put up a green-and-white sign similar to other states'; its wooden welcome emblem is something you'd actually want to pose with in a photo.

items.title: ARIZONA
items.caption: Arizona's flag and its most recognizable tourist landmark—that would be the Grand Canyon—are the focal points of its interstate signs.

items.title: ARKANSAS
items.caption: Did you know that Arkansas's nickname is "The Natural State"? If you've crossed the state's borders, you should: The moniker—a reference to its plethora of mountains, lakes, hot springs, and more—is right there on the welcome signs.

items.title: CALIFORNIA
items.caption: Instead of using a more recognizable symbol on its state signs—like the coastline, or an orange, or something like that—California's DOT instead chose to add a poppy, the state flower, to its highway signs.

items.title: COLORADO
items.caption: Colorado's cheerful, rustic signs (there are 40 throughout the state) have become landmarks in and of themselves, with each one weighing about 150 pounds.

items.title: CONNECTICUT
items.caption: Connecticut may be full of surprises, but this welcome sign—a plain blue-and-white number—is not one of them.

items.title: DELAWARE
items.caption: Delaware's sign is nice and all, but in this case, we can only think of Wayne Campbell: "[Hi…I'm in Delaware.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DDGDgc1qNCA)"

items.title: FLORIDA
items.caption: Florida calls out some its most recognizable state symbols—the palm tree and the orange—on its welcome signs. (No Mickey Mouse, though. Huh.) The state DOT plans to replace these signs with bigger and more photogenic ones by 2015.

items.title: GEORGIA
items.caption: "Georgia On My Mind" is the official song of the Peach State, so it's only fitting that a snippet of the lyrics (along with a fuzzy peach) ended up on its welcome signs.

items.title: HAWAII
items.caption: Fun fact: Hawaii doesn't have specific state welcome signs on its highways; instead, they're located at Hawaiian airports, like the one in Honolulu.

items.title: IDAHO
items.caption: Not even a potato, Idaho? Fine.

items.title: ILLINOIS
items.caption: Of course Illinois would call out its most famous son: 16th President Abraham Lincoln, who lived in the state, became a congressman there, and was buried in Springfield after his 1865 assassination.

items.title: INDIANA
items.caption: Indiana's nickname, "The Crossroads of America," is a reference to the fact that several major interstate roads passed through the state. And thus, it ended up on its highway signs.

items.title: IOWA
items.caption: One of Iowa's biggest tourist attractions is the _Field of Dreams_ house, so of course that movie is referenced on the state's highway signs.

items.title: KANSAS
items.caption: Kansas's signs are a mishmash of its state seal (emblazoned with the Latin phrase "Ad Astra per Aspera," translating to "To the Stars Through Difficulties") and the state flag, which features a sunflower, the official state flower.

items.title: KENTUCKY
items.caption: Kentucky's state motto is "Unbridled Spirit"—like horses, because of the Kentucky Derby, see—and so it ended up on the state signs, which also feature a subtle horse illustration.

items.title: LOUISIANA
items.caption: A fleur-de-lis and the phrase "Bienvenue en Louisiane" are shoutouts to Louisiana's Cajun French culture, still a vital part of the state's identity.
items.credit: © David R. Frazier Photolibrary, Inc. / Alamy

items.title: MAINE
items.caption: We'll take Maine's word that things in Maine are, indeed, the way life should be.

items.title: MARYLAND
items.caption: Maryland's signs are positively cluttered with state iconography: The red, yellow, and black state flag is perched above black-eyed Susans, the state flower.

items.title: MASSACHUSETTS
items.caption: We can't say for sure whether you'll actually see a chickadee sitting on a Mayflower when you visit Massachusetts (both are emblems of the state), but you sure will on its highway signs.
items.credit: Massachussetts Office of Travel and Tourism

items.title: MICHIGAN
items.caption: The Great Lakes State adopted the "Pure Michigan" slogan in 2006 as part of an advertising campaign, and its since permeated much of the official tourism literature in the state—including the welcome signs.

items.title: MINNESOTA
items.caption: University of Minnesota students are responsible for the current welcome sign, created in 1996; the Department of Transportation wanted to hark back to the [old highway markers](http://www.dot.state.mn.us/restareas/entry-signs/es-history.html), but with a more modern design.

items.title: MISSISSIPPI
items.caption: Mississippi has had several state signs, including one that highlighted its place in rock 'n' roll history; this one is simple but effective, with the state flower—the magnolia—perched in a corner.

items.title: MISSOURI
items.caption: Missouri's slightly befuddling nickname, "The Show Me State," greets travelers as they cross state lines.

items.title: MONTANA
items.caption: Montana's welcome signs got a makeover in 2013, replacing decades-old iconography with images that highlight some of the unique elements of the state: cowboys, Bighorn Canyon, and the like.

items.title: NEBRASKA
items.caption: In case you didn't know, Nebraska is the home of Arbor Day. You learn something new every day.…

items.title: NEVADA
items.caption: The "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas" sign is more well known, but these welcome signs exist, too; they complement a similar license plate that was introduced in 1989.

items.title: NEW HAMPSHIRE
items.caption: Following a rebranding campaign, New Hampshire also updated its welcome signs in 2012—the French is a nod to its Canadian visitors, a major influence on the state's culture.
items.credit: Kethaneni/Courtesy New Hampshire Division of Travel and Tourism

items.title: NEW JERSEY
items.caption: New Jersey has several welcome signs, and this one is a darn sight nicer than the ones that welcome you to the Turnpike, that's for sure.

items.title: NEW MEXICO
items.caption: New Mexico's welcome signs reference its state flag, with red and yellow coloring, and its agriculture, with red or green chiles on various signs.

items.title: NEW YORK
items.caption: How long do you think it'll be before the lyrics from "Empire State of Mind" end up on New York's welcome signs? We give it another five years.

items.title: NORTH CAROLINA
items.caption: North Carolina keeps it simple and classy, with its state flag the only adornment on its highway signs.

items.title: NORTH DAKOTA
items.caption: Depending on where you enter North Dakota, you might see a different sign: This one, featuring the visage of President Theodore Roosevelt, is an entrance to the state's western region (conveniently, where Theodore Roosevelt National Park is located).

items.title: OHIO
items.caption: Another simple, clean design. We dig it, Ohio.

items.title: OKLAHOMA
items.caption: Less a sign and more a big monument to the state, this sign along an Oklahoma interstate is more imposing than your standard-issue welcome wagon.

items.title: OREGON
items.caption: Travelers heading into Oregon from California will see this massive sign along Interstate 5, where it was installed in 2010.

items.title: PENNSYLVANIA
items.caption: The slogan "State of Independence" was added to Pennsylvania's welcome signs in 2004, after a campaign to remind folks of its place in American history.

items.title: RHODE ISLAND
items.caption: These may be the newest welcome signs in the USA: Five of these markers were installed earlier this summer, with another two to follow in the coming months.
items.credit: Courtesy Rhode Island Department of Transportation

items.title: SOUTH CAROLINA
items.caption: Though South Carolina has these fairly staid markers along its interstates, we'd be remiss if we didn't mention [South of the Border](http://www.thesouthoftheborder.com/history/), the supremely tacky roadside stop that's just over the North Carolina-South Carolina border.

items.title: SOUTH DAKOTA
items.caption: What else do you put on a welcome sign for South Dakota than the state's—nay, one of the country's—biggest attractions?

items.title: TENNESSEE
items.caption: Why "the Volunteer State"? It's a [holdover from the War of 1812](http://www.tennessee.gov/tsla/exhibits/veterans/mexicanamerican.htm), when thousands of Tennessee men willingly went to fight against the British.

items.title: TEXAS
items.caption: We were expecting something bigger, bolder, and…well, more Texas than these signs. But the state flag and the DOT's "Drive Friendly" motto are nice too, we guess.

items.title: UTAH
items.caption: Utah created seven different welcome signs, which are placed at strategic points around the state. This one, for example, can be found around the Lake Powell region; another, featuring a ski bunny, is installed near Park City and other popular ski spots.

items.title: VERMONT
items.caption: Vermont keeps things simple: illustration of Green Mountains, state name, nickname that echoes the whole mountain theme. Boom. Done.
items.credit: Courtesy Vermont Department of Tourism & Marketing

items.title: VIRGINIA
items.caption: Similar to its fellow commonwealth, Massachusetts, Virginia festooned its welcome signs with the state bird (the cardinal) sitting atop the state flower (an American dogwood).

items.title: WASHINGTON
items.caption: Way to keep it simple, Washington.

items.title: WEST VIRGINIA
items.caption: "Wild and Wonderful," a popular slogan in West Virginia, was added to the welcome signs in 2007.

items.title: WISCONSIN
items.caption: Wisconsin's welcome signs are charmingly retro: 23 of these markers, made from redwood, were installed along major highways beginning in 1958—and remarkably, they're still standing.

items.title: WYOMING
items.caption:
Don't expect to see Wyoming's welcome signs for too long: According to the state's tourism office, they change out every so often, along with the state license plates.




What's your favorite state sign? [Vote now in our poll](http://poll.fm/4vxa0), and see which welcome sign fellow travelers like best.




**More ways to celebrate America:**




[Which State Has the Coolest License Plate in America?](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/best-license-plate-vote)




[10 American Monuments to See In Your Lifetime](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/patriotic-4th-of-july-monuments-and-destinations)




[The 10 Biggest 4th of July Fireworks Displays in the U.S.](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/the-10-biggest-fireworks-displays-in-the-us)

fields.bio: Amy Plitt is a Brooklyn-based writer and digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler.* She has written for such publications as *Rolling Stone,* the A.V. Club, *Foam*, Made Man, *Mental Floss*, and *Time Out New York*, where she was a staff editor. She's also the author of *[Subway Adventure Guide: New York City](http://www.triumphbooks.com/subway-adventure-guide--new-york-city-products-9781629370774.php?page_id=21)* (Triumph Books), a guidebook about the ends of New York City's subway lines. When she travels, she's on the lookout for excellent local beers, weird museums, and nerdy historical sites.

featureContentItems.hed: Photos: Inside New Mexico's Nakashima Church
featureContentItems.dek: On a recent trip to New Mexico, photographer Mikael Kennedy discovered an architectural gem amid the remote wilderness of the Chama Canyon.

items.caption: I have been exploring New Mexico since 1999, returning about once a year for various reasons. I’ve been in every part of the state and I thought I had seen everything there was to see, but, just before my last trip west, a friend mentioned that there’s a church in the middle of the desert designed by the famous Japanese-American architect and furniture maker George Nakashima. “Go find it, “ she told me, and nothing else.

A little online research revealed that the church is called “[The Monastery of Christ in the Desert](http://christdesert.org/)” and is located in the Chama Canyon in the remote north-central region of the state—about 75 miles from Santa Fe and not far from [Georgia O’Keeffe’s Ghost Ranch](http://www.ghostranch.org/) in Abiquiu.

The church is at the end of a 13-mile dirt lane, officially labeled “Forest Service Road 151” and accessed by U.S. Route 84. The service road winds along the river, cutting through the landscape as it takes you deeper into Chama Canyon. We didn’t pass any other cars along that little road, which was a blessing, as I’m not sure how we would have navigated past another vehicle.

When you arrive at the Church, you park on the edge of the property and follow a winding path through the brush. As you snake your way along, you see the church peeking out through the vegetation, backed by the magnificent red cliffs of the canyon, eagles circling slowly overhead.

The path winds slowly toward the church, with several stops at large wooden crosses, each one numbered and inscribed. The intention seems to be to force you to slow down your procession, to force moments of introspection. Each cross faces a different direction, which lets you see the canyon from several angles.

As we walked into the empty church, we could hear monks chanting in the distance. Since we didn’t see anyone, we quietly wandered around the main chapel. The most striking thing about the space is the large windows that look out at the canyon walls, hinting that the canyon and nature are the actual church, and the building is just a small part of it.

We wandered into an adjoining building that housed a small gift shop, still not having seen a soul. In the shop, I bought a bar of soap made by the monks, leaving exact change in a basket by the door. As we were leaving, a woman came out from one of the other rooms carrying lunch that she had made for the monks. She told us that she had come to this place 20 years ago. She had been so taken with the church and the surrounding wilderness that she decided to stay, camping by the river for many years before she was invited to stay and live with the monks. We said goodbye and she continued with her work.

As we walked back along the winding path to our car, surrounded by such silence, the church receding into the canyons walls, slowly being enveloped by the desert, I could understand why the woman we met in the gift shop had decided to stay.

fields.bio: [Mikael Kennedy](http://www.mikaelkennedy.com/#/portfolio/Portfolios/0/0) is a New York City based commercial and fine art photographer. Coverage of his blend of art & fashion photography has appeared in the Wall Street Journal, The New Yorker, Time, WWD, GQ, & Esquire. His polaroid work is part of the permanent collection at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, TX, as well as in private collections worldwide.

featureContentItems.hed: 8 Traditional Korean Temples That Allow Overnight Stays
featureContentItems.dek: These temple stays make for an experience like none other, whether it's sleeping under a 100-foot Buddha statue or sharing tea with monks.

items.title: Bongeunsa
items.caption:
Seoul, South Korea


----------


Buddhism has a 1,700-year history in Korea, marked by the many temples hidden away in the mountains—a few you can even stay in. With a Seoul address, Bongeunsa is unique in that it's located in an urban area. The temple has been around for 1,200 years, and today it serves as the center of Buddhist practice in South Korea. Should you choose to extend your visit, you can participate in a temple tour, tea ceremony, meditation, rosary making, and spending time with the monks themselves. Visit [TempleStay.com](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/reservation.asp?cid=9&idx=1&schedule_idx=88#schedule2) for more information.

items.title: Woljeongsa
items.caption:
Pyeongchang, Gangwon Province 


----------


Hidden back in a fir tree forest on Odaesan, a mountain just two hours outside of Seoul, is [Woljeongsa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=17#schedule). The temple is famous for its nine-story pagoda. Overnight programs at the temple offer meditation, as well as participation in 108 prostrations, communal work, and prayer bead threading.

items.title: Geumsansa
items.caption:
Gimje, North Jeolla Province


----------


[Geumsansa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=25#schedule) is one of Korea's most popular temples to call home for a few days. It invites visitors to share tea and conversation with the resident monks and take lessons on Seon (Korean Zen) meditation. The temple sits at the foothills of beautiful Moaksan, which Koreans know as Mother Mountain.

items.title: Beomeosa
items.caption:
Busan, South Korea


----------


[Beomeosa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=5#schedule) is a tiered temple perched on the side of the mountain Geumjeongsan in Busan, Korea’s second largest city located on its southeastern coast. Beomeosa is regarded as the main temple for Seon meditation, and it offers overnight programs focused on the topic. Guests can participate in meditation and quiet contemplation, conversations with monks, and traditional tea ceremonies.

items.title: Haeinsa
items.caption:
Gayasan National Park, South Gyeongsang Province
____
[Haeinsa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=40#schedule) is one of Korea’s Three Jewel Temples, making it one of the most famous Buddhist sights in the country. Aside from its beauty, the temple is home to the Tripitaka Koreana, a collection of 81,258 tablets containing Buddhist writings. The structure they’re housed in has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage site. The temple offers overnight guests a chance to participate in meditation walks that begin with the dawn ringing of the Dharma drum, along with plenty of interaction with the resident monks.
items.credit: © LOOK Die Bildagentur der Fotografen GmbH / Alamy

items.title: Yakcheonsa
items.caption:
Seogwipo, Jeju Island


----------


[Yakcheonsa](http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=1725699) is a relatively new temple (built in the 1990s), located on Jeju Island off the southern coast of South Korea. It claims to be Asia’s biggest temple and is definitely worthy of an extended visit. Participants in Yakcheonsa’s temple stay program are offered the usual activities, such as Zen and walking meditation, with the added bonus of experiencing it all among palm trees.

items.title: Beopjusa
items.caption:
Songnisan National Park, North Chungcheong Province


----------


[Beopjusa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=55#schedule) is one of Korea’s most famous temples. Located on Mount Songni in Songnisan National Park, the temple is home to numerous national treasures. Sleep in the shadow of a 100-foot gilded bronze Buddha statue, visit the five-story pagoda, or walk through one of Korea’s three major Buddhist halls adorned with *dancheong* (traditional decorative painting) during your stay.

items.title: Golgulsa
items.caption:
Gyeongju, North Gyeongsang Province


----------


Located just outside of Gyeongju, one of Korea’s most culturally rich cities, [Golgulsa](http://eng.templestay.com/reservation/temple_view.asp?cid=9&idx=32#schedule) is the only cave temple in Korea. A temple stay at Golgulsa will find you admiring Buddha sculptures carved into rocks and practicing the meditative martial art known as Sunmudo.
