fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

featureContentItems.hed: The Restaurant Guide to Portland, Maine
featureContentItems.dek: It may be the smaller and lesser-known Portland, but New England’s Portland is gaining a reputation as a city for food lovers, with a slew of award-winning restaurants recognized nationwide. Here’s our guide to where to eat and drink in this seaside city.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: The Restaurant Guide to Portland, Maine
featureContentItems.seoDescription: It may be the smaller and lesser-known Portland, but New England’s Portland is gaining a big reputation on the foodie scene, with a slew of award-winning restaurants recognized nationwide. Here’s our guide to where to eat, drink and snack in this seaside city.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: The Restaurant Guide to Portland, Maine
featureContentItems.socialDescription: It may be the smaller and lesser-known Portland, but New England’s Portland is gaining a big reputation on the foodie scene, with a slew of award-winning restaurants recognized nationwide. Here’s our guide to where to eat, drink and snack in this seaside city.

items.title: [Eventide Oyster Co.](http://www.eventideoysterco.com/%29)
items.caption: Although it’s relatively new on the scene, Eventide made a big splash with its extensive raw oyster bar carved out of a giant hunk of granite. You’ll find it packed with ice and at least ten Maine oyster varieties, making Eventide is one of the best places to taste local seafood. If you prefer to skip the raw stuff, try the nutty, buttery oyster stew or the brown butter lobster roll.

items.title: [Empire Chinese Kitchen](http://www.portlandempire.com/kitchen/index.html)
items.caption: When Empire opened in the early 1900s, it was Portland's first Chinese restaurant. Now, it’s reimagining that cuisine for a newer generation of Portlanders: this year, it reopened as a dim sum restaurant, serving traditional dumplings and small plates alongside sumptuous lobster lo mein and bacon fried rice.
items.credit: Courtesy Ted Axelrod of Spoon and Shutter

items.title: [Piccolo](http://piccolomaine.com/)
items.caption: This tiny trattoria in downtown Portland is currently only open for dinner and weekend brunch, but it's worth the inevitable wait to sample chef Damian Sansonetti's (Bar Boloud) interpretations of Southern Italian cuisine. Dishes are made with a mix of house-made ingredients (including pastas) as well as items imported straight from Italy.

items.title: [Slab](http://slabportland.com/)
items.caption: Somehow, Slab manages to serve thick-crust, Sicilian-inspired pizza that's actually quite light and fluffy—Portland-based food photographer [Ted Axelrod](http://www.axelrodphotography.com/) describes the tomato-and-cheese topped slices as a “pizza pillow," which is pretty accurate. Try the original slab, which is served as a single hand-sized piece (unless you want to go big and get a half- or full-sized slab), or sample one of the specialty slices, topped with ingredients like giardinara or pepperoni.
items.credit: Courtesy Ted Axelrod of Spoon and Shutter

items.title: [Miyake](http://www.miyakerestaurants.com/)
items.caption: Since 2011, Chef Masa Miyake has been wowing diners with his sushi dishes, which combine flavors from his native Japan with techniques he picked up while working in French and Italian kitchens. If you go for dinner, let Chef Miyake himself guide you with the nightly *omakase* (chef's choice) menu. But the local trick is to scoot in at lunchtime for their midweek special: two sushi rolls for $10, or a bento box for $18.

items.title: [Caiola's ](http://www.caiolas.com/)
items.caption: Locals love Caiola’s for their delicious brunch, especially on their secret deck in the summer months. Try the paella (made with fresh Maine seafood, of course) to share between two people, or their polenta fries.
items.credit: Courtesy Ted Axelrod of Spoon and Shutter

items.title: [OhNo Cafe](http://www.ohnocafe.com/)
items.caption: Best known for its breakfast bagel sandwiches made to order (and a wide selection of hot sauces to spice them up), OhNo is also an excellent place to pick up a few beers from local brewers (including Bissell Brothers or Rising Tide Brewing Company) with a sandwich before a trip to the beach.

items.title: [Petite Jacqueline](http://bistropj.com/)
items.caption: Named for the owner’s grandmother, Petite Jacqueline feels like a Parisian neighborhood café. Its menu is packed with French staples like a croque-madame sandwich, but come for the rotating daily specials: on a cold day, there’s often fondue or steak au poivre to keep you warm.
items.credit: Courtesy Ted Axelrod of Spoon and Shutter

items.title: [Zapoteca](http://www.zapotecarestaurant.com/)
items.caption: Zapoteca may serve delicious Mexican food, but the restaurant's drink list is also worth the trip. They have a thorough tequila list and lots of margarita options, like watermelon-habanero flavor (pictured). Zapoteca’s executive chef and owner Shannon Bard has a cookbook, *Gourmet Mexican Kitchen,* scheduled for release in February 2015, so you can try to replicate her citrus-rubbed chicken or flavorful mole sauces at home.
items.credit: Courtesy Ted Axelrod for Gourmet Mexican Kitchen

items.title: [Holy Donut](http://www.theholydonut.com/)
items.caption: The Holy Donut has two locations where you can find delicious and filling donuts, made with Maine potatoes and sweet potatoes. There are plenty of gluten-free and vegan options, plus unusual flavors like dark chocolate with toasted coconut, or sweet potato with ginger sugar. Both locations close when they sell out, so get there early.

fields.name: Emily Westbrooks
fields.shortBio: Emily Westbrooks is a Dublin-based writer, founder of [From China Village,](http://www.fromchinavillage.com/) and author of [Delightful Dublin](http://www.delightfuldublin.com/), an e-guide to her adopted city.
fields.bio: Emily Westbrooks is a Dublin-based freelance writer and blogger, passionately sharing her tips for getting the best of Dublin on her lifestyle, design, and travel blog [From China Village](http://www.fromchinavillage.com/). She is the author of a beautiful and useful travel guide to her adopted home, called [Delightful Dublin](http://www.delightfuldublin.com/). If you find her in Dublin, she's likely sipping a coffee in a cafe with her husband and daydreaming about her next adventure.

featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53db229fdcd5888e145e75c9]|||Virgin America's The Loft at LAX|||

I recently spent an afternoon curled up in a Vitra Alcove day bed, drinking Blueberry VeeV Daiquiris, nibbling on small plates of soba noodles and sushi, and soaking up the panoramic view as day turned to night. No, I was not at some decadent beach bar. I was stranded at LAX. My [travel plans had imploded](http://www.cntraveler.com/perrin-post/2013/09/three-tips-to-avoid-a-missed-flight-nightmare), and I found myself with several hours to kill in Virgin America's Terminal 3 club lounge, [The Loft](http://www.virginamerica.com/vx/lax-loft). Not only were there complimentary tropical cocktails, but there were also many of the comforts of home—including high-speed Wi-Fi, a large-screen TV, even peanut butter, jelly, bread, and a toaster. (And all for an entry fee of $40 if you're flying Virgin America or a partner airline.)



As nice as such perks might sound, they actually pale in comparison to what you can find in the finest airport club lounges worldwide. Here are some of the most spoil-you-rotten perks encountered by frequent first-class flier Gary Leff, who writes [View From The Wing](http://boardingarea.com/viewfromthewing/2013/12/07/worlds-best-airport-lounges/), as well as the airport aficionados over at [LoungeBuddy](http://www.loungebuddy.com/), the must-have app for finding the best lounge when you're stuck at the airport.



The Thai Airways First Class Lounge in Bangkok gives guests an [hour-long spa treatment](http://boardingarea.com/onemileatatime/2012/04/06/the-last-aeroplan-hurrah-thai-airways-first-class-lounge-spa-bangkok/). "Nothing can beat an hour-long Thai massage prior to flight," says Leff.







 The Lufthansa First Class Terminal in Frankfurt summons Porsches and Mercedeses that [drive you right to your plane](http://crankyflier.com/2011/05/17/the-new-first-class-experience-on-lufthansa/) when your flight is ready to depart. "Other lounges that provide tarmac transfer, albeit in more limited circumstances, are the Lufthansa first-class lounge on the B concourse in Frankfurt, the Lufthansa first-class lounge in Munich, the Swiss first-class lounge in Zurich, and the Air France first-class lounge in Paris," adds Leff.







 The Qatar Airways Premium Terminal in Doha has a [luxury jacuzzi](http://efficientasianman.com/2013/06/12/trip-report-around-the-world-in-100-hours-qatar-airways-first-class-premium-terminal-doha/) and sauna.







 The First Class section of Cathay Pacific's "The Wing" lounge in Hong Kong has [private "cabanas"](http://blog.sleepinginairports.net/2013/03/03/cathay-pacific-first-class-lounge-features-cabanas-and-champagne-bar/) for freshening up. "They come complete with a bathtub, shower, day bed, and room to get work done," says LoungeBuddy co-founder Brent Griffith. There are also 12 luxury shower suites, just in case you don't need a whole cabana.







 The [SkyTeam Lounge](http://www.jaunted.com/story/2011/4/5/95238/61991/travel/Inside+the+SkyTeam+Lounge+in+Terminal+4+at+London-Heathrow) at Heathrow in London offers an "oxygen bar." You get "10-minute sessions of pure oxygen," says Griffith, "including a choice of individual flavored scents like citrus or pure air."







 The "F*** Me I'm Famous" [lounge in Ibiza](http://www.irishtimes.com/blogs/ontherecord/2013/06/07/checking-in-at-david-guettas-airport-lounge/), the Spanish island famous for its nightlife and electronic music, was developed by Grammy Award-winning musician David Guetta and has a DJ booth and dance floor.







 The Turkish Airlines CIP Lounge in Istanbul has a [billiard table](http://first2board.com/foodwineandmiles/2013/10/03/visiting-turkish-airlines-business-class-lounge-istanbul/).







 The Virgin Atlantic Clubhouse at London's Heathrow has a [recording studio](http://blog.virgin-atlantic.com/t5/Our-Experience/New-Recording-Studio-at-Virgin-Atlantic-Clubhouse/ba-p/1671#.Uq8mExxZw-0) and digital editing room for music mixing, just in case you dream up a new tune while waiting for a flight and don't want to forget it.







 Speaking of making music, the [Asiana Business](http://boardingarea.com/frequentlyflying/2013/10/29/lounge-review-asiana-business-class-seoul-incheon-midfield-concourse/) and FirstClass Lounges in Seoul have a piano available for use by "guests who are aspiring musical virtuosos," says Griffith.







 The Virgin Atlantic Clubhouse at New York's J.F.K. has a Bumble & Bumble [hair salon](http://blog.virgin-atlantic.com/t5/Our-Experience/Virgin-Atlantic-Unveils-New-JFK-Clubhouse/ba-p/1531#.Uq8nwhxZw-0).







 The Korean Air first class lounge in Seoul makes personalized metal luggage tags for its guests upon request. [Here are the ones custom-made for Leff](http://boardingarea.com/viewfromthewing/2012/12/23/suites-treats-and-eats-a-malaysian-mileage-thanksgiving-korean-airlines-first-class-kuala-lumpur-seoul-and-the-korean-airlines-first-class-lounge-seoul/).







 The United Club at Tokyo's Narita airport has a pretty cool [beer machine](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vCV9Ha0zCTU).



**Have you found a better airport lounge perk? I'd love to hear about it. What was it, and where?**



 



**Related:**



[These New Airport Lounges Can Save the Day](http://www.cntraveler.com/perrin-post/2013/10/these-new-airport-lounges-can-save-the-day-if-you-re-delayed)



[A Must-Have App for Airport Delays](http://www.cntraveler.com/perrin-post/2013/10/a-must-have-app-for-airport-delays)



[Virgin Atlantic v. British Airways: Battle of the Airport Lounge](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/05/virgin-british-airways-airport-lounge-smackdown)

fields.name: Wendy Perrin
fields.bio: Wendy is the founder and editor of [WendyPerrin.com](http://www.wendyperrin.com/).  She is also TripAdvisor’s first-ever Travel Advocate, sharing her advice with TripAdvisor’s visitors.  Formerly, as *Condé Nast Traveler*’s Director of Consumer News and Digital Community, Wendy wrote the magazine’s travel advice column The Perrin Report for 17 years, The Perrin Post blog for eight years, and The Perrin Postcard newsletter for four years. She started out long ago as the magazine’s Ombudsman, investigating reader complaints about travel companies and helping wronged travelers get compensation, and that led to her book *Wendy Perrin’s Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know* (Fodor’s).

featureContentItems.hed: Peru’s First National Museum to Open on Archaeological Site
featureContentItems.dek: A Peruvian architect has been chosen to design his country's first-ever National Museum.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/547bd4c72a3d21fa285cb2ca]|||
Lima, Peru.
|||


Peru will soon begin construction on its first large-scale national museum. Located southeast of Lima, in the valley of the Lurin River, the museum will serve as the entry point to the Pachacámac ruins, a sanctuary which houses ancient pyramidal temples and squares. The grounds date back to around 200 A.D. and were constructed over the centuries by several different cultures, including the Huari, the Ichma, and the Incas. It will be called the Museo Nacional del Perú (National Museum of Peru).

While the ruins will be central to the museum’s focus, contemporary art will also play a major role in the museum’s collection. The 49,000 square foot space will have an estimated 500,000 artifacts, as well as a library, classrooms and laboratories to promote modern science, and the education of the national heritage of Peru. It will also absorb most of the collections of two existing museums: the Museum of the Nation and the Museum of Archaeology, Anthropology, and History of Free People.


[#gallery: /galleries/5421c5c8cf292a6830da13c7]||||||




The museum’s modern design is the vision of Peruvian architect Alexia León Angell, who beat out close to one hundred entrants in a competition hosted by the Peruvian government. Though the museum will be far outside the city center – 25 miles from Lima – it’s been reported that the Ministry of Culture is in talks with the Municipality of Lima to find new and convenient ways for visitors to reach the outlying destination. Hyperallergic [has some renderings](http://hyperallergic.com/177546/at-long-last-peru-gets-a-national-museum/) of what the interior and exterior of the museum will look like.

Construction on the museum will reportedly begin once archaeological studies are completed sometime this year, with the museum’s full completion expected in April or May of 2016. Though dates are fuzzy as to when one can officially visit, there’s no doubt that this museum’s opening will cause a flurry of excitement the world over for its inventive collaboration between ancient ruins, and modern art.

fields.name: Liz Dosta
fields.shortBio: Research editor at Condé Nast Traveler
fields.bio: Liz Dosta was born in Japan, and raised in southern California. She holds an MFA in poetry from Columbia University where she was a teaching fellow. Her writing has appeared in *The New York Observer, The Atlas Review*, *Paper* magazine, and Bustle, among others. Currently, she is the research editor at *Condé Nast Traveler* magazine, and has worked for a range of publications, including *The New Yorker*, and MoMA. She is also a portrait artist, and a voracious reader of mystery novels.

featureContentItems.dek: Whether it’s a scent, a special snack, or a specific pair of shoes, everyone has *something* they’re always sure to bring with them on a trip. Here, seven frequent travelers  (and expert packers) share what they’d never leave home without.

items.title: High-quality headphones
items.caption: “I never travel without a book and my headphones,” says film and media producer [Tahiti Huetter](http://www.tahitihuetter.com). “These are [Frends](http://www.wearefrends.com), which are not only stylish, but noise-canceling, too.” As for music? “I love to listen to an album in its entirety when I’m on a flight,” Huetter continues. “Some favorites include Emily Wells’s *Mama*, Alt-J’s *An Awesome Wave*, and Fink’s *Perfect Darkness*.”

items.title: Essential oils
items.caption: “I swear by essential oils,” says California-based photographer [Jennifer Young](http://jenniferyoungstudio.com). “My must-haves are lavender, which is very calming, and peppermint, which can help with headaches or nausea. When you’re on the go, deep breathing and aromatherapy are so powerful in smoothing over any bumps in the road along the way. Being well-rested helps, too — my secret is [Pharma Gaba](http://www.iherb.com/Natural-Factors-Stress-Relax-Pharma-GABA-100-mg-60-Veggie-Caps/8905) as needed, and this [charcoal eye mask](http://rikumo.com/products/binchotan-charcoal-eye-mask), which helps with circulation.”

items.title: A home-cooked lunch
items.caption: “Because I’m gluten intolerant and airplane food is never very good, I always pack my own lunch, usually something with grains and vegetables,” says [Aran Goyoaga](http://www.cannellevanille.com), a food writer and photographer. For those looking to follow suit, we love the clean design of these [San Yoshi bento bowls](http://www.momastore.org/museum/moma/ProductDisplay_Bento%20Bowl_10451_10001_190171_-1_26707_26707_188072), which are non-breakable and easy to spot in the dark depths of a carry-on.

items.title: Two pairs of shoes
items.caption: Says travel photographer [Jinna Yang](http://greaseandglamour.com), whose packing routine has been streamlined to include only the essentials, “I bring one pair of sneakers for comfort during the day — I swear by [Nike Roshe](http://store.nike.com/us/en_us/pw/roshe-run/c6i) — and a pair of flats or ankle boots for night. I look for pairs that are waterproof but still look classic. [Aigle makes](http://www.aigleboots.com) great ones.”

items.title: Smart accessories
items.caption: “On any given travel day, you’ll find us wearing our [Speakeasy travel scarves](http://speakeasytravelsupply.com/collections/frontpage/products/pacific-trails-mist), which have a hidden pocket where we keep our phones and passports,” say travel bloggers [Randy Kalp and Bethany Salvon](http://beersandbeans.com). “We also like [ExOfficio underwear](http://www.exofficio.com/products/womens/underwear/bottoms), which is designed to be easily packed, washed, and dried while on the go. To carry it all, we use the [Tom Bihn Packing Cube Backpack](http://www.tombihn.com/PROD/TB0925.html), which doubles as a daypack or market bag.”

items.title: A dependable backpack
items.caption: “My first backpacking trip took me to seven countries with various climates and cultural norms over the course of six months,” says Lauren Kilberg of the blog [Double Takes](http://www.doubletakesblog.com). “My [Osprey Ariel 55 backpack](http://www.ospreypacks.com/en/product/womens/ariel_55_1_1) never did me wrong and held everything I need — and it’s come with me to over 25 countries since. I keep it organized by packing everything in mesh laundry bags meant for delicates. It makes taking things out and putting them back in again so much easier.”

items.title: A roomy carry-on
items.caption: “I rarely check a bag,” says travel blogger [Oneika Raymond](http://www.oneika-the-traveller.com). I like to pack light — one rolling carry-on, and one of two leather bags I bought on a trip to Europe a few summers ago (both are pictured here). They’re everything I need them to be: easy to carry, durable, and roomy enough to hold my 11-inch Macbook Air, toiletries, makeup, wallet, phone, and Canon 600D DSLR. They’re also versatile enough to serve as an everyday bag while I’m on my trip.”
